item.title: A Million Evacuated as Typhoon Fung-Wong Hit the Philippines
item.description: Grabbing children and leaving their homes behind, residents evacuated before Typhoon Fung-wong hit.

item.title: Syria’s President to Meet Trump at White House for First Time
item.description: The visit by President Ahmed al-Shara is another step in the transformation of the former rebel leader once wanted by the United States as a terrorist.

item.title: F.B.I. Director Is Said to Have Made a Pledge to Head of MI5, Then Broken It
item.description: The episode has contributed to concerns among intelligence allies that Kash Patel, brash and partisan, is also unpredictable and even unreliable.

item.title: Juan Gabriel Tribute Draws Tens of Thousands to Mexico City
item.description: The transgressive icon of Mexican music, who died in 2016, still has millions of fans. On Saturday, more than 170,000 filled Mexico City’s central plaza to watch footage of a landmark concert.

item.title: Syria al-Shara al-Baghdadi Trump
item.description: In 2019, President Trump sent U.S. commandos to to a small village in Syria to kill the leader of the terror group Islamic State. On Monday, Syria’s president, a former associate of that leader, will meet Mr. Trump in the White House.

item.title: As the Russia War Continues, Ukraine Faces a Major Draft Evasion Problem
item.description: Ukraine faces a major draft evasion problem, but no place is quite like Vylkove, a Danube River town where men of draft age have all but vanished, many of them trying to avoid military service.

item.title: Why Children of Unmarried Mothers Are Stranded in Saudi Arabia
item.description: We pieced together the details, from Riyadh to Nairobi.

item.title: Why Everyone Wants to Meet the ‘World’s Most Boring Man’
item.description: Politicians, oil giants and climate activists hang on his every word. The Trump administration has blasted him. How did Fatih Birol get so big?

item.title: Unwed Mothers and Their Children Are Trapped in Saudi Arabia
item.description: A Times investigation found that children are routinely deprived of birth certificates, medical care and education. Diplomats and police officers turned the mothers away.

item.title: Drones Over North Korea Were Part of Martial Law Bid in South, Special Counsel Says
item.description: South Korea’s ousted leader, Yoon Suk Yeol, was accused of trying to stoke military tensions to justify his short-lived martial law last December.

item.title: He Was Known for Kleptocratic Rule and Bloodshed. Now Suharto Is a National Hero.
item.description: Indonesia’s president bestowed the honor on the dictator Suharto, who died in 2008, in what many said was a stunning move of revisionist history.

item.title: Tackling Climate Change Without the U.S.
item.description: This year’s U.N. climate talks are being held in Brazil. So far, they’ve been noteworthy for who isn’t attending.

item.title: Medical Marijuana Grower in New Zealand Faces Criminal Charges
item.description: A police raid and criminal case against a longtime cultivator of cannabis in New Zealand’s Northland region has stirred up debates about medicinal marijuana.

item.title: Hundreds of Migrants Missing Off Malaysia’s Coast
item.description: A boat said to be carrying people from the Rohingya ethnic minority capsized, and another was missing. At least seven bodies were recovered.

item.title: Second Migrant Child Dies on ‘Reverse Migration’ Boat Route
item.description: A 3-year-old from Colombia died when a boat carrying migrants back to South America capsized off Panama’s Caribbean Coast, an official said. Another child drowned on the same migrant route in February.

item.title: Inside Trump’s Deportation of Venezuelans: Four Months in a Salvadoran Prison
item.description: The Times interviewed dozens of migrant men sent to a prison in El Salvador by the Trump administration. Independent forensic analysts called the testimony credible and consistent and said the treatment met the U.N.’s definition of torture.

item.title: BBC Director Tim Davie and CEO Deborah Turness Quit Following Trump Documentary Turmoil
item.description: The abrupt moves followed furor over claims that a documentary had misleadingly edited footage of President Trump’s speech before the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

item.title: Super Typhoon Fung-wong Hits Philippines Days After Last Storm
item.description: Typhoon Fung-wong made landfall on the main island of Luzon, prompting the evacuation of more than one million people, just days after an earlier storm killed over 200.

item.title: Hamas Hands Over Body of Hadar Goldin, Israeli Soldier Held Since 2014
item.description: Hamas returned to Israel the remains of Lt. Hadar Goldin, who was killed in a 2014 war in Gaza.

item.title: As Aquifers Dry Up, Tehran Rations Water and Calls for Rain Prayers
item.description: Facing Iran’s worst drought in 60 years, the country’s president warned that the capital might need to be evacuated, and some locals promoted cloud-theft conspiracy theories.

item.title: Argentina Has Become an Escape for L.G.B.T.Q. Russians Escaping Putin’s Anti-Gay Crackdown
item.description: Argentina has emerged as a surprisingly prominent destination for L.G.B.T.Q. Russians escaping President Vladimir V. Putin’s escalating anti-gay repression.

item.title: After Hurricane Melissa, Solar Power Kept the Electricity on for Some Jamaicans
item.description: People with rooftop solar panels got their power back almost immediately. The ‘entire neighborhood benefits,’ one resident said.

item.title: Tornado Rips Through Southern Brazil, Killing at Least 5
item.description: Pounding rain and winds of over 150 miles per hour left a trail of devastation in the state of Paraná.

item.title: Japan Lifts Tsunami Advisory After Strong Earthquake Off Its Coast
item.description: A 6.7-magnitude quake struck off Japan’s coast early Sunday evening, prompting a tsunami advisory, which was later lifted.

item.title: What Questions Do You Have About Climate Change?
item.description: “Ask a Correspondent” will take your questions to Somini Sengupta, our international climate reporter.

item.title: The Dangerous Stalemate Over Iran’s Nuclear Program
item.description: With no negotiations, no oversight and no clarity about Iran’s stock of nuclear material, many in the region fear another war with Israel is inevitable.

item.title: Charting the History of New York’s Middle Eastern Community
item.description: A New York Public Library exhibition features nearly two centuries of cultural, social and political artifacts on Middle Easterners and North Africans in the city.

item.title: TikTok’s ‘Millennial Baroness’ Starts to Branch Out
item.description: Leonie von Ungern-Sternberg built a social media following by talking about her family’s history — both good and bad. Now she’s ready to talk about the rest of her life.

item.title: A Quebec Writer Confronts His ‘Little Darkness’ as a Class Defector
item.description: Jean-Philippe Pleau’s book and play about moving up socially became a cultural reckoning in Quebec, but created a gulf with his family.

item.title: Israeli Academics Find Themselves Isolated Despite Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: Boycotts of Israeli universities, largely imposed in Europe, have multiplied since the start of the war and reflect Israel’s international isolation over its conduct in Gaza.

item.title: Spain’s True-Crime Capital Is Fed Up
item.description: A decades-old killing in a tiny village in a northern mountain town has turned the village into a destination for true-crime enthusiasts, creating a headache for remaining residents.

item.title: Russian Bombardment Causes Large Outages in Ukraine’s Big Cities
item.description: The attack by Russian missiles and drones targeted the capital, Kyiv, and the large cities of Dnipro and Kharkiv, as well as several smaller municipalities.

item.title: Anthony Grey, Journalist Held Hostage by China for Two Years, Dies at 87
item.description: A correspondent for Reuters, he became a global symbol of China’s isolation and of the anti-foreigner hysteria spawned by its Cultural Revolution.

item.title: In Cozying Up to Trump, Leaders Hedge Their Reliance on Moscow and Beijing
item.description: President Trump has made it easier for countries that are close to Russia and China to build ties with the United States. Those countries are embracing the opportunity.

item.title: What I Learned From the ‘New Globalists’ of an Optimistic Nation
item.description: Few countries are excited about globalization anymore, but Vietnam is still into it — wholeheartedly. Do the reasons go beyond economic growth?

item.title: Fatos Nano, Albanian Leader in Era of Chaos and Transition, Dies at 73
item.description: A political survivor during his country’s shift from brutal communist regime to flawed democracy, he served three stints as prime minister.

item.title: A Powerful Tool to Override Constitutional Rights Goes to Court
item.description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments in two cases involving provinces using a clause to pass laws that violate the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

item.title: Inside China’s Quest to Defy Aging with Longevity Labs and ‘Immortality Islands’
item.description: Longevity labs, “immortality islands” and grapeseed pills are part of China’s national project to conquer aging, despite sometimes shaky science and extravagant claims.

item.title: Saudi Ex-Intelligence Official Seeks American Help Spilling U.S. Secrets
item.description: Saad Aljabri, feuding with the de facto Saudi ruler, wants former U.S. officials to help him fend off Saudi corruption claims.

item.title: 4 Arrested Over Disruption of Israeli Orchestra’s Concert
item.description: Several audience members shouted or lit flares as the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra performed in Paris. After the concert, the ensemble received 10 minutes of applause and played the Israeli national anthem.

item.title: Trump Signals Openness to Exempting Hungary from Russian Oil Sanctions
item.description: Despite a chummy relationship, new U.S. penalties on Russian energy were likely to be a sticking point as President Trump and Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary met.

item.title: Canada Culls Hundreds of Ostriches as a Court and a Kennedy Fail to Save Them
item.description: The birds, exposed to the avian flu, were killed after Canada’s Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal and a rescue effort by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. fell short.

item.title: Prince Harry Apologizes to Canadians for Wearing an L.A. Dodgers Cap
item.description: Harry, who referred to the episode as “Hat Gate,” was seen wearing the cap at a World Series game in Los Angeles between the Dodgers and the Toronto Blue Jays.

item.title: Leaders at COP30 Climate Summit in Belém Focus on the Rising Toll of Warming
item.description: “All we have to do is look outside,” one delegate said. “The sea rises, the coral dies.”

item.title: Russian Jailed for Placing Tiny Antiwar Signs in a Market Says She Would Do it Again
item.description: Freed in a major prisoner swap, Aleksandra Skochilenko said “the values of freedom of speech, of peace, could be more important than spending even 10 years in jail.”

item.title: Serbian Lawmakers Approve Luxury Trump Hotel on Historic Bombing Site
item.description: Despite a fraud investigation into officials who endorsed the project, Parliament used an extraordinary provision in the Constitution to push the plans through.

item.title: U.S. Wants Security Council to Adopt Trump Plan for Gaza
item.description: The alternative, Ambassador Michael Waltz bluntly told diplomats, was to watch the cease-fire between Israel and Hamas give way to a return to war.

item.title: As Saudi Arabia Cracks Down on Drugs, Executions Near a Record High
item.description: Facing an influx of amphetamines, the kingdom has put hundreds of people to death, many of them foreigners convicted of low-level smuggling.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Scar Canadian City Where Cars Have Been Made for Decades
item.description: An automaker’s decision to shift Canadian jobs to the United States has left workers in Brampton, Ontario, feeling betrayed and angry.

item.title: Why Germany Is Still Divided When It Comes to Russia
item.description: Many East Germans are more sympathetic toward Moscow than their western compatriots, reflecting decades of Soviet ties and disillusionment since reunification.

item.title: Former King of Spain, Juan Carlos, Details Death of Brother in Memoir
item.description: He wrote about the accident that killed his brother nearly 70 years ago. The book also describes his respect for Gen. Francisco Franco, the former dictator.

item.title: China’s New Aircraft Carrier Enters Service, a Sign of Naval Ambitions
item.description: The Fujian, China’s most advanced carrier, went into official service this week. It brings the country closer to challenging U.S. naval dominance.

item.title: Testosterone and Women’s Sex Drive
item.description: My colleague Susan Dominus discusses her reporting on women who are taking testosterone — in some cases lots of it.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Removes Syria’s President From Sanctions List
item.description: The decision comes days before the Syrian president, Ahmed al-Shara, is expected in Washington for the first time since he came to power.

item.title: How Radio Traffic Let Us Track U.S. Drones in the Caribbean
item.description: The U.S. military’s buildup near Venezuela has been rapidly growing and changing. Riley Mellen, from Visual Investigations, describes what’s visible, and audible, about the deployment.

item.title: Sexual Assault of Mexico’s President Exposes Challenges of Her Equality Push
item.description: President Claudia Sheinbaum was groped on the street this week, in an episode that set off a national conversation about what has and has not changed since Mexico elected its first female leader.

item.title: U.S. Sends Attack Aircraft to El Salvador Amid Regional Troop Buildup
item.description: A New York Times analysis of satellite imagery and air traffic control communications found that U.S. military planes began operating out of the Central American country in mid-October.

item.title: Iran Sentences Iranian American Jewish Man to Prison, Family Says
item.description: Kamran Hekmati of Long Island was arrested for visiting Israel 13 years ago to celebrate his son’s bar mitzvah, they said.

item.title: Why Is Trump Threatening to Intervene In Nigeria?
item.description: President Trump has threatened to send troops to Nigeria, where he says Christianity faces an “existential threat,” an accusation that Nigeria has denied. Ruth Maclean, our West Africa bureau chief, describes how the violence in Nigeria is affecting people of all religions, not only Christians.
